Information concerning the hazards of ammonia includes toxicity data, permissible exposure limits, physical, reactivity, corrosivity, thermal, and stability data, and the effects of inadvertent mixing.  Information concerning the process technology includes process flow information, process chemistry, maximum intended inventory, safe upper and lower process limits, and consequences of deviating from safe limits.  Information concerning the process equipment includes the materials of construction, piping specifications, piping and instrumentation diagrams, electrical area classificaiton, relief design calculations and design basis, design codes and standards employed, material and energy balances, and safety systems.

Process Hazard Analysis
Lost Pines 1 has a comprehensive program to ensure that the hazards associated with the regulated process are systematically identified and controlled.  The analysis is conducted in accordance with regulatory requirements, general industry standards, and guidance from safety organizations such as the Center for Chemical Process Safety.  The plant has a system in place to ensure that recommendations resulting from this anaylsis are resolved in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
Lost Pines 1 maintains written operating procedures that address the various modes of process operations, including; initial startup, routine startup and shutdown, emergency shutdown, emergency operation, routine operation, and temporary operation.  The procedures also detail safe upper and lower process limits, consequences of deviation from safe limits, and how to return the process to safe operation.  The procedures are readily available to all operations personnel, and are reviewed and certified annually.

The Lower Colorado River Authority (LCRA) and GenTex Power Corp.  has a long-standing commmitment to worker and public safety.  The commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  It is the policy of LCRA/GenTex to implement reasonable controls to prevent forseeable releases of regulated substances.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
The Lost Pines 1 Power Plant, located in Bastrop County, Texas, is a gas-fired combined cycle power plant that produces electricity.  As a means of reducing nitrogen oxide emissions from the two gas-fired combustion turbines, anhydrous ammonia is injected into the turbine exhaust streams.  The anhydrous ammonia is stored on-site in two storage tanks located on opposite sides of the plant.  The capacity of each tank exceeds the threshold quantity for RMP applicability.

Accidental Release Prevention Program
Lost Pines 1 is subject to OSHA's PSM standard and Program 3 of EPA's RMP rule.  The accidental release prevention program at Lost Pines 1 includes:

All Lost Pines 1 employees are actively encouraged to participate in the accidental release prevention program.  Each employee is encouraged to participate in the continual upgrade and maintenance of all health and safety programs.  Employee involvement is achieved through direct participation on a voluntary basis, active consultation with affected employees, and representative participation in the process hazard analysis.  Employees have access to all information required under the PSM and RMP regulations.

Process Safety Information
Lost Pines 1 maintains a variety of technical documents to ensure that the process hazards are understood and that the plant is operated and maintained in a safe manner.  These documents include information concerning the hazards of ammonia, process technology, and process equip

rocess.  Operations personnel receive refresher training every three years.

Contractors
Lost Pines 1 uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors may work on or near the ammonia process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors are aware of the hazards of the process, understand what to do in the event of an emergency, understand site safety rules, and inform plant personnel of any hazards they encounter in the course of their work.  The plant also evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection process.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR)
Lost Pines 1 conducts a pre-startup safety review for any new facility or significant facility modification.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety systems, procedures, training, and equipment are prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check to verify that construction is in accordance with design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quailty assurance function by requiring verification that accidental release prevention programs are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity
Lost Pines 1 has implemented practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The program includes: (1) the development of a maintenance schedule for equipment in the ammonia process  and critical safety equipment, (2) development of written maintenance procedures, (3) conducting maintenance training, (4) performing and documenting inspections, (5) correctiohjn of identified deficiencies, and (6) application of quality assurance measures to ensure that replacement equipment meets applicable speci

fications.

Hot Work Permits
Lost Pines 1 has an active hot work program in place to ensure worker and process safety.  The hot work permit program is designed to control spark-producing activities and to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before work begins in the process area.  These procedures (and others) along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that maintenance activities are performed safely.

Management of Change
Lost Pines 1 has a system in place to ensure that safety concerns associated with changes to the ammonia process are reviewed and addressed prior to making any change.  The changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards as well as to verify that existing controls will not be compromised by the change.  The system requires that process safety information and operating procedures are updated and that operations and maintenance personnel are trained before the change is implemented.

Incident Investigation
Lost Pines 1 will promptly investigate all incidents that have resulted in, or could reasonably be expected to result in, the catastrophic release of ammonia.  The findings of the investigation, along with any corrective actions taken to prevent recurrence of the incident, will be reviewed with all affected personnel, including contractors as appropriate.

Compliance Audits
To ensure that the accidental release prevention program is functioning properly, Lost Pines 1 will conduct a compliance audit every three years.  The plant will quickly resolve any deficiencies noted by the audit team and will review the audit report and corrective actions taken with all affected personnel.

Additional Safety Systems
Lost Pines 1 has additional systems in place to prevent accidental releases of ammonia, as well as systems to lessen the impact of accidental releases.  These systems include:

* Redundant instrumentation to monitor critical process parameters
* Redundant critical

equipment
* Automated shutdown systems
* Pressure relief valves
* Water deluge system to wash ammonia vapors from the air

LCRA/GenTex continuously evaluates the safety systems and operating procedures associated with the covered process to determine if there are ways to improve safety.  If an improvement is found, LCRA/GenTex will take steps to evaluate and implement it in a timely manner. Five Year Accident History
The Lost Pines 1 Power Plant began commercial operations in May 2001.  There have been no RMP accidents at the plant.

Emergency Response Program
The Lost Pines 1 Power Plant maintains a written emergency response program.  The program addresses all measures, evacuation plans and personnel accounting, notification of emergency response agencies, and emergency response procedures.  The emergency response program is coordinated with the Bastrop Local Emergency Planning Committee.
